review_title: Tremendous Improvements Made, More Expected to Follow
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: The Dean and CEO Bob Grossman is making enormous changes, most of them very good. Some of the old guard is resistant to change, which can account for much fo the grumbling. Grossman is ever-present, very positive, a talented physician, and an extraordinary fundraiser. He has spent the last three-plus years clearing out dead wood and attracting new talent. This is a very exciting place to work. How many Medical Centers have recieved four $100 million+ gifts from donors in such a short time span: none.
cons: My con is more of a personal one.  If I worked for a different senior manager, I would be having a much better experience. My manager rewards mediocrity and is fearful of anyone who has as much if not more intelligence and experience than she. Enough about that. The big con for me is the cost of health care for those who pick the out-of-network plan. Unless you have a catastrophic event, you will pay for most of any out-of-network care.

job_title: Registered Nurse in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits. Good coworkers depending on the unit.
cons:
To say that this hospital's culture is abysmal--is an understatement. This hospital has created a culture in which every little thing that you do or did not do is nitpicked or is made into a big deal. Managers will pull you into their offices and will proceed to question you about nonsense, insult your integrity  and diminish your work ethic. They treat you as if you just committed murder no matter which issue.

Most people from nursing management and above have little to no clinical or bedside experience.  So, they have no idea how to relate or support their staff when there is a"problem".  What I find hilarious is that these are the same people who encourages you to get your certifications, do projects and get your Master's, etc.  Why? So they can take credit for YOUR work. How? Because not only will they look good to the rest of management, it will also look fantastic for "Magnet". As a result, you end up with a bunch of sycophants trying to outdo the other and a nice dose of pretentiousness. 

Stay clear of this institution. It only seems great on the surface.  But, it is a revolving door and there is a reason why.

I would rather work hard in a mediocre hospital than in this institution and its pretentious drivel.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great location, beautiful hospital, great hospital environment, seems to be a place where growth is possible, respectful and staff throughout the hospital such as lobby desk and cafeteria.
cons: I've been at NYU for 2 weeks and considering quitting. I should not feel like it's a death sentence to go to work because I am uncomfortable. Most of the employees are sweet hardworking people. What makes it miserable...the bad employees, who constantly get away with everything because they are tight with management. There is one particular employee who continously belittles another. They have made offensive comments, even sexually. They use their cell phones and work is never done. I've raised concerns to more veteran employees and all I get is to mind my business and leave it alone. I've asked about reporting the employee to management and all I hear is they already know but, will do nothing about it. This person is also the managements eyes and ears and everything they say is believed. This employee will disappear for 30 mins and if you're late from break 3 minutes  they will call management to report. I've come to the realization that nothing will be done and it's time for me to go. I came to this organization with so much hope and excitement and I can't believe that I'm ready to throw in the towel 2 weeks in.

job_title: Patient Unit Associate in Brooklyn, NY
pros:
The Benefits are great, if you are a Full-Time employed union staff the Hospital pays into the 1199 Union Benefit fund which affords the union worker generous full medical and dental coverage for you and your spouse if your married. 
Generous paid vacation and paid time off benefits. NYU does not offer union workers 401k retirement plan instead they offer 403b retirement plan without a match so you have to pay for your own retirement.   Other than that non union workers are offered a different package, work life balance is great and work culture at NYU is all incusive with tons of room for growth and easy to move up in the company.
cons: retirement plans with no match, other than that no complaints.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Brooklyn, NY
pros: The cafeteria and coffee shop. Other then that I can't see any other pros to working at this hospital. Brooklyn is a great place I was born there.
cons: A lot of nurse bullying and nurses eating their young. When you are in recruitment they reassure you that you will be guided and supported and that you won't be thrown to the wolves. The problem is there are the wolves but they come in sheep's clothing. The patients are not the problem it's the nurse educators some of them are truly nice but the others are old and mean and crank and should retire. All it takes is a few bad apples to spoil the whole bunch plus your first experience in the nursing field. The sad fact is the administration turns a blind eye to it even when you have concrete proof and witnesses. They turn around and blame you. And at this point you haven't even gotten on the floor yet. Wow if nurses can't support and learn from each other in a non threatening environment then how can they effectively treat their patients. Very sad about the profession. I can only hope that as the old nurses retire the new generation of nurse will have learned enough about bullying in school to eliminate it from the profession.

review_title: NYU Langone Health is an excellent place to work
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: I have been working at NYU Langone Health for over 25 years.   NYU has afforded me the opportunity for endless growth and continuous learning.  The benefits are outstanding. The salaries offered are extremely competitive in the NYC area.   I love to come to work each day as I am surrounded by the best team and supported by leadership at all levels including our executive team.    In my role I am given the opportunity to implement change to keep NYU at the cutting edge.   Throughout all my years at NYU I believe all of my work was recognized and valued .   This is a place to work where your voice is heard and your opinion matters.  NYU Langone Health is an excellent place to work.
cons: There are none to mention.   I would not work anywhere else in NYC.

review_title: Great Company With a TERRIBLE Internal Career Program
job_title: Project Associate in New York, NY
pros: The staff at the School of Medicine are great people who genuinely care about the work they are doing. The compensation is fair for the work you do and significantly higher than nearby medical centers.
cons: They constantly promote their internal career "Steps for Sucess" program that is seemingly nonexistent when you actually apply. I worked at NYU Langone for two years while I obtained my master's degree, and very much wanted to stay within NYU Langone to continue my career.  However, the internal career planning team never reached out to me after I submitted my application, though the internal website states all applicants are to be contacted within a week or so. I even emailed the contact & mentioned it to the career planning team representative at an internal career fair, and they assured me that my application/resume would be reviewed and I would be contacted. I ended up leaving the organization I loved because I was never contacted despite all my efforts. I don't know if they ever got around to my application months later, as they close your email account upon leaving the organization.

review_title: Good culture but bad for long-term research staff
job_title: Assistant Research Scientist (With An MS Degree) in New York, NY
pros: People are nice.  Good benefits such as 22 vacation days and 403K, but you don't get paid enough to go on a vacation or put any money into the retirement account if you are a researcher.  For IT and others, during the 12 years I spent at NYU, I've seen people go elsewhere and come back again saying that NYU was much better working environment.
cons: Not really the insituttion's fault.  But if you are a research staffer that gets paid from an NIH grant, you don't get paid enough for the cost of living. It's alright for those who are just starting out and want the name of the well known instiatuion on their resumes, but unless you get a faculty position, this is not a place to stay for a long time.  Even though those in research get paid very little, since it is in NYC, the institution seems to have no shortage of people who want to come and work from outside the country, therefore, no incentive to do anything about it either.

job_title: Pracice Manager in New York, NY
pros:
Ability to meet people from all walks of life
Ability to move up within the organization is much more refined than what I've seen at other institutions
cons:
Support departments are not as robust as other institutions (payroll, finance, MCIT, etc.) especially in the area of keeping up with the times. For example, MyTime was just implemented about 2 years ago while this system and its refinements has been a standard in other institutions for almost 10 years. Same goes for payroll systems, finance systems (Accounts payable, purchasing) and MCIT (support to manage needs across the institutional.
Seems as if institution is growing and expanding faster than what it can handle in terms of standards (emergency management, environmental health and safety, etc) and if the same expectation, in terms of patient safety, revenue and output is expected all across the institution, support to do this doesn't seem to be keeping up with expansion, nor being relayed to staff who may be asking these same exact questions

job_title: Medical Biller in New York, NY
pros: Pay was better than expected
cons: Everything! No communication with mgmt. seem to care but so fake.

job_title: Assistant Director in New York, NY
pros: An abundance of smart, motivated employees. They have worked hard under leadership that has pushed for a rise in the rankings of the facilities and the school, and have succeeded.
cons: There is a reason senior management gets a low grade on Glassdoor, despite its accomplishments. Some of the departmental managers lack the skill set to manage effectively, and they are allowed to stumble along. So poor behavior is accepted and in some cases even rewarded. Managing up is what's recognized, so there are too many skilled politicians with weak skills that get undeserved recognition. There are some really fantastic people who end up leaving.

job_title: NYU Postdoctoral in New York, NY
pros: nothing its a bad place to work
cons: nyu orthopedic hospital is a micromanaging hospital

job_title: Food Service Host in New York, NY
pros: Beautiful Facilities, Buildings and Friendly Co-Workers.
cons: The department i worked for made you feel like you didn't have a voice. It was also hard to transfer out of the department due to  desperate competition and seniority positions. It might have the highest turnover rate in the company. They didn't do much to boost morale. It was one of the most depressing and stressful jobs I've ever had and I'm sure that many who have left and are still there will agree. They overworked their employees to the point where no one wanted to sign up for overtime. They made us feel like line workers.

review_title: Don't get comfortable. If you think your going to retire here, think again.
job_title: Manager in New York, NY
pros: The compensation, upward mobility and everything about this company speaks to level of growth. There are many teaching modules to learn other skills, and the co-workers are top notched professionals.
cons: Senior Leadership is horrible. Its like playing in the school yard with mean kids, nerds, and jocks. The clique-type attitude among the women is disgraceful and there are no minority men in leadership. Business office is mostly woman. HR are two-faced, elitist, that take senior leadership opinion over employees. They hire and retain the services of mostly White, African American woman, Indian, and Asian. No African American males need apply.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Good Healthcare and clean facility.
cons: After 11 years working in this facility I was lay- off with the promised of a new job in a new department. This was my offer,  a low paid job, less money of what I was making when I got hired 11 years ago Before I find out about this offer for 3 weeks I had to chased HR , which on those 3 weeks the representative was off for 11 days.  He got back 2 days prior for me loosing my job. He was never prepared or had the right information to provided me with, and the last day of my facility getting closed down, after I ended up calling him, since he never called me, as he said he would,  he provided me with the same low paid job, but this time he offered me even less money for this position. When I question him about it, he totally ignored me and did not offered any reasonable answer. I requested for everything to be put on writing and send by email. Never Happen.

job_title: Child Life Specialist in New York, NY
pros:
Excellent benefits 
East River views
New building
cons:
Management can be difficult
Morale has dropped significantly since the move to Kimmel
New CFO pushes revenue raising over patient experience
Staff not awarded bonuses after a tough year with many people working extra unpaid hours and covering for positions that were not allowed to be filled 
HR not interested in supporting staff and don't want to hear anything negative 
EVERYTHING is "at the discretion of your manager" so even if you get 24 days leave a year, there's a good chance you won't be allowed to take them, or when you want to take them.

review_title: Good place to do a neuroscience postdoc, though can't avoid the downsides of a postdoc
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in New York, NY
pros: I work in neuroscience, and NYU has quickly become a top place for this field. It has a diverse mix of research, with both established giants and fantastic up-and-coming young PIs. It is a dynamic and exciting community, and New York City is generally a fantastic place for neuroscience right now.
cons: NYU can't avoid the general downsides of postdoctoral positions, and everything depends pretty heavily on the laboratory PI, culture, resources, funding, etc. But postdocs know what they're getting into, so that won't come as a surprise. NYUMC does have a lot of bureaucracy. I went to a smaller, more focused school for my PhD, which had some advantages for the scientific staff. But the work/life/social culture at NYU is generally quite good amongst the researchers.

review_title: Business Side is Not a Nice Place to Work
job_title: Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Pay is very good for a hospital. Pretty spacious (for NY) offices on Park Ave. Decent benefits. Good NYSC discount. Name recognition. Easy hours.
cons: Weirdly competitive environment. Directors can be petty and inappropriate. Mistakes are not tolerated (which causes staff to be cautious to the point of not taking initiative). Directors will occasionally yell at employees in front of others. 'Thank you's are rare. Culture of critical feedback with no positive reinforcement. Supervisors are afraid of directors and will not look out for their employees. No growth path. Management actively seeks ways to make you feel you could be fired at any time (but will then be devastated when you quit). If you are looking for a job where you can learn and grow, explore and have your good work rewarded (or even just a job where you can take pride in your work and not be made to cry), this is not it.

review_title: Don't get your hopes up for fair promotions even if you deserve them, but the benefits are ahh-mazing.
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: 5 weeks vacation; mostly 9-5; tution remission; part of huge team (~80 people) which can be inspiring as there are many people to learn from; raising money for really impressive medical programs, institutes, and physicians that make huge impact.
cons: VP has control/trust issues that prevent her from entrusting her senior team to make decisions and in turn, trust those on their individual teams. This creates an environment where people feel second guessed and unable to own their work fully which makes people miserable.

job_title: Manager in New York, NY
pros: Good compensation and friendly culture. PTO is OK.
cons: No diversity for people of color in senior management role. If your African-American, seeking a leadership role; you only will be considered for Administrative support roles (Admin, finance rep, customer service). Communication between staff and leadership is a problem. HR supports leadership over employees all the time. If you have a complaint, learn to live with it. HR is mostly figureheads who hire only from the NYU graduate schools. If you get an interview, your satisfying HR's monthly quota of hire, not because your qualified. If your international physician, you had to have studied in UK for any consideration.

job_title: PC Technician in Mineola, NY
pros:
Close Knit with coworkers, work well together, Close to train station 
If you have been there for many years you can change your schedule easily to adjust a school schedule I've been FT, PT, PD and have taken leaves for medical conditions for both myself and my family
NYU has come to save us from a business standpoint which hopefully facilitates Pt. care
cons:
No room for advancement, Lower paying, New Staff in every discipline get paid more than those that have been there longer, ANM's cause more problems than helping facilitate Pt. care, a little disorganized
You do end up paying more for insurance if you are PT or PD then you make which is not conducive when you have to shell out copays, coinsurances, and pay for medications that the hospital doesn't carry, dental plan and vision plans are not good

review_title: Overall, NYULMC is a good place to work.
job_title: Environmental Health & Safety Specialist in New York, NY
pros: The organization does a good job of providing perks for their employees. While there aren't any bonuses, they provide discounts for health clubs, wellness programs, commuter shuttle and other benefits to staff. They also are big on work life balance which is a plus.
cons:
The structure/culture within the department needs work. The "buddy" system they have is not set up correctly and needs to be redone. This system along with the "unwritten" rules are very ingrained in the office culture and can be difficult for new staff to adapt to. Management is very hands off and inaccessible to new staff. Manager and some co-workers were rude and unprofessional.
The hardest parts of the job for me was trying to fit in with the office culture, working under a manipulative co-worker and keeping up with the large workload.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: You are surrounded by good people who work very hard and are very passionate about their job.  The insurance, retirement and other benefits are great.  The mission is powerful and something that you can agree with intellectually.
cons: There isn't enough work life balance.  Reviews have gone out to the employees and we've said as much but not much has happened since we are too busy working to notice our loved ones are missing us and tired of the hours.  There also is very little personal/professional development.  Although it exists on paper, we're working too many hours to benefit.  It is clear they care about their people but there just isn't enough of them to get the job done so we all suffer.

review_title: Great Floor Management & Opportunities; Upper Management Only Cares About Money.
job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in New York, NY
pros: Great management; great nurses on my floor-lots of new grads. Movement up encouraged. Great pay. Pay will increase the longer you remain at the hospital.
cons: Hiring freeze after covid does not allow for any OT at all (can never clock out if you stay late and there are huge PCT shortages without the option for OT). Need to hire more staff. Need to compensate health care professionals for the hours they remain after work when crisis occur should as rapids, codes, and late admissions.

review_title: the analogy is : you get what you pay for
job_title: in New York, NY
pros:
tuition benefits for the employee and the employee's kids
health insurance and dental insurance is not bad
access to the hospital facilities if you are on a PPO or even HMO
job stability - won't get affected by the financial crisis .. i hope.
cons:
average pay is lower
not sure if this is applicable to all departments; but growth is extremely slow
pay hikes are very small
the benefits department is extremely ignorant. 
a lot of information that needs to be forwarded by the HR and benefits department to all the employees is not done in a correct manner and/or on a regular basis.

job_title: Senior Animal Research Technician in New York, NY
pros: Decent salary for non-entry level positions.
cons:
The DCM department (formerly known as DLAR) overworks their staff with mandatory overtime (50-60 hrs/week) which includes weekends and holidays. They are constantly short-staffed and unable to retain new employees, fast turnover rate, unwilling to acknowledge faults and improvements that need to be made within management. There is an overall hostile environment between management and their employees.

Lobby security personnel are unprofessional, in a hospital setting patients should not be struggling to open doors. Cleaning services should not be harassing guests to finish using the restrooms. There is an overall below average quality level of service that one would not expect from a "top" Manhattan hospital.

job_title: Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Good benefits. Some really great, talented people.
cons: Was once a great place to work. With rapid over-expansion and carpetbagger managers & 'leaders' with connections and no relevant work experience brought on to slam projects in, the integrity of the workplace suffered greatly. People are still leaving in droves, as they should. They did one Gallup survey & the numbers were so low that it was never repeated. HR will always side with management, even if the manager is a bona fide psychopath. It's pretty much a girls club of angry former nurses at the top. You will never encounter more sad, vicious women except maybe if you change careers and work in a women's prison. No need to apply. If it's your last NYC option, relocate.

job_title: Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: Great organization to work for. Facilities are state of the art and research departments are all centrally located in midtown manhattan (East). Really good benefits and work/life balance is just right. Great first job for anyone looking to start their career.
cons: Research teams are very independent. That means that every PI runs their team in a different way and collaboration with other teams is limited and completely dependent on PI. That also means that your growth potential is also limited by the needs of team you work for.

job_title: Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: I worked as a research associate although my first title was project assistant when I started. My entire team and I got promoted  after 2 years because of structural changes they made to the project, Other than being forced to "promote" us there isn't much opportunity for growth or movement as an RA in general. Overall, decent starting salary for someone who was a recent college grad and great time-off policies... although my actual supervisor preferred for us only to take off during certain times of the year.
cons: The company values are strong and ultimately heading in the right direction. You get the sense of everyone working towards a common goal and they have a very team driven atmosphere. The benefits are again pretty solid and very good. The leadership tends to be a little prickly but ultimately you don't have to deal with them directly unless its at functions, etc.

review_title: Exciting place to work for IT professionals.
job_title: Senior IT Analyst in New York, NY
pros: The hospital and school leadership are some of the smartest people I have worked with.  The clinical staff is dedicated to quality patient care.  The SOM has developed some unique technology to enable virtual learning and collaboration.
cons: IT Management has implemented a culture of blame.  System failures are investigated to find out who is to blame.  In a misguided attempt to portray themselves as tough no-nonsense leaders IT management will discipline individuals for human error.  This behavior has a devastating effect on morale.

job_title: Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Good work hours. Relatively good co workers for the most part. Lots of decent places to eat in the area. Good retention bonuses for epic staff right now.
cons: Management can tend to be clueless about what it takes to get projects done. Some of them just like to listen to the sound of their own voice. Lots of favoritism. Did not really respect the executive leadership from what I can see. No real growth opportunities or chances of getting promoted unless the people above you are fired or promoted.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
NYU Langone is truly a pioneer in world-class medicine and the compensation and benefits are amazing.  
Friendly community, lots of great people to work with and easy to get behind the brand name.
cons: Management can be stifling, especially if your job falls outside the normal purview of hospital operations (Doctor, nurse, office staff, etc).  In my current role, I find myself unable to complete certain tasks because they're at odds with hospital policy.  Also, there is very little room to manage up and any dissent whatsoever, even in an attempt to create better policies and procedures is met with hostility

review_title: It could be great for you at NYU Langone Medical Center!
job_title: Management in New York, NY
pros: There are a variety of fields and career paths persons can follow.  Jobs are not limited to health care or research. If one chooses to change careers they need not apply outside the company. The company offers employees a career track to advance their careers. Senior management keeps the community well informed of the ongoings of the organization and employees seem to have a passion about the company
cons: The health coverage and tuition reimbursement are not comparable to other reputable organizations in the area. Employees pay pay too much out of pocket expenses for their health coverage and tuition reimbursement is limited to secondary degree programs at NYU only.  Management is still a very top-down approach with males dominating the senior level positions.

review_title: Fast paced research environment with plenty of opportunities to network and expand your scientific knowledge.
job_title: Graduate Student in New York, NY
pros: One of the highest stipends for graduate students in the country and cutting edge research centers and cores. Faculty are extremely intelligent and innovative with regard to the research projects that you are able to participate in. Additionally, there is a good amount of collaboration and fluidity between departments so that you can pretty much work on what interests you ( to some extent). One of the most ethnically diverse bio-medical graduate programs in the country.
cons: Low pay compared to cost of living (but manageable) and time off ( sick leave, maternity leave, vacation time, etc. ) is sometimes left up to the sole discretion of the principle investigator with whom you work which can be difficult to negotiate if they are unwilling to give you time off that you need.

job_title: IT Project Manager in New York, NY
pros:
Started as a contractor,  and have seen firsthand the many growth opportunities that are available within the hospital and within MCIT, the department that I have worked in for over 5 years.  MCIT is a place that nurtures its resources, and opportunities are plentiful, not just for professional growth and development, but also for new initiatives as well.  

Benefits are amazing, and continue to improve.  When I first started, there wasn't paid maternity leave, and now there is (both from the state and from NYU Langone).  Education reimbursement has increased, and there are many employee discounts available.  There's also financial incentives for staying healthy.
cons: It's a very large organization, and navigating the various benefits available has been difficult at times.  Different employees have different benefits so it's not always helpful to speak with a fellow colleague.

job_title: Registered Nurse in New York, NY
pros: Tuition reimbursement, reputable company, benefit packages, retirement matching, excellent staff of doctors
cons: Disorganized ambulatory centers with imbalance in staffing assignments.  Weak management unable to determine staffing assignments.  Many call outs which would further the burden of work.  Found out I was making 10,000 less than a co worker and asked for a raise, which I was denied.  Got a new job and they offered 15,000 over my salary....I left because that was just ridiculous management.

review_title: Great Experience for a Future in Neuroscience
job_title: Intern in New York, NY
pros: Everybody works together as a team, from the principal investigator to the lab assistants; in fact, everybody often goes out together on Fridays to cement those relationships.  People generally respect and support each other, working hard to make sure that research has been completed with due diligence.  I feel that primarily, effective communication is the best feature of working here.
cons: A volunteer's pay (0), but that's to be expected.  There's some drama in the office, though that can be entertaining so long as you're not involved.  People work extremely long hours to complete projects, but this is of course academia.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Good Benefits, some very talented co-workers

job_title: FGP Assistant in New York, NY

Manager is clueless. Has no idea how to manage.
Has others do all her work. Adminstration will never support the staff unless you complain to HR. Staff afraid to speak up due to being fired or retaliation. Too many meetings about the same thing. Supervisor overlooks some of the employees whom are always late to work. Also plays the blame game on others who really do work. No structure in the office. Lack of communication. Some of the Doctors have no manners, they only speak to the staff  unless they need help.

job_title: Anonymous in Brooklyn, NY
pros:
-Nice people, for the most part, decent communication for a hospital btw floor staff and admin for dept
-Pay/benefits 
-Brooklyn location

-Hiring: For permanent employees seems to have slowed. A rise in temp workers is worrisome. Hospital STILL needs high-performing, permanent dedicated staff even if $ isn't allotted.
-People are uneasy: No one knows what the merge -actually- means w regards to positions. 
-NYU (manhattan) gave very obscure promises at merge

review_title: management vs. clinical staff differences are stark
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros: work-life balance; decent location; great colleagues; rapidly growing due to major acquisitions in NYC area; affiliations with NYU; appears to value research in theory (but not practice). hospital and doctors do care about its patients in departments I observed.
cons: super bureaucratic; operational inefficiencies; high operational risk due to key-person dependencies; error-prone HR that is slow and makes mistakes with onboarding / salaries / benefits. the culture of management is also more around "distrust" than trust (e.g., employees need to finger-press every day). doesn't allow flex time options.

review_title: ELIMINATING EMPLOYEE Tuition Benefit for DEPENDENTS paves way for NYU to Provide Free Medical School for STUDENTS
job_title: Senior Analyst in New York, NY
pros: other benefits, location, annual cost of living increase tied to annual merit based performance
cons: Staff tuition benefit was ELIMINATED for dependents, years before free medical school was announced; senior leadership salary doubles while staff benefits are outright reduced; middle management very out of touch with their staff despite “training” and they enjoy increased benefits when compared to their staff, above and beyond what’s publicly published in the summary plan description; morale is terrible

review_title: Excellent Hospital and a Great Place to Work!
job_title: Benefit Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros: NYU Langone Health is committed to excellence.  We are provided with top equipment, and the institution makes a tremendous effort to simplify our lives so we can focus on our work.  Our goals are clear, our managers are accountable and we enjoy top class employee benefits.  It is exciting to be a part of this institution.
cons: Things change quickly, and we have experienced a great deal of growth and expansion.  Flexibility is crucial to succeeding at NYU Langone Health.

job_title: Data Scientist in New York, NY
pros:
* Some of the kindest team members (and people) I have met.  
* There is an emphasis on employee happiness to garner results from management high up.  
* Members of my team and other teams are incredibly talented yet humble and always willing to learn.
* Work closely with academics and have the opportunity to be on published works.
* The work is fulfilling.  Everything we do is to bring better care to patients and reduce stress among physicians.
cons:
* Things can move slowly with such a large company when going outside of your team for help.
* With a smaller team, some structure is lacking in the development processes.
* Health data is messy and can be frustrating to work with.
* There are little opportunities for performance based benefits / bonuses.

review_title: Overall a good place to work, needs to focus on creating the same cross departmental policies for fairness
job_title: Web Manager in New York, NY
pros:
Pay in line with average, if you self advocate for a higher salary when you interview for the job they will consider it. I did and was successful.
Good health benefits, as you'd expect working for a medical center.

Automatic 3.5% yearly raises (provided you aren't written up, etc)  6% company match to your 401k or 403b after 6 month probationary period. Employee must contribute 3% to get the match, which isn't very much to ask. 

HR is very good about providing protections so people cant be fired off-hand, just because a boss dosen't like the way you look, etc. 

Get to work with very intelligent people who are mostly nice

You can get full tuition reimbursement for classes related to your position at the med center, if the classes are unrelated, i believe its 80% reimbursement.  You do pay taxes on the classes though as the IRS treats it as a gift. 
You get to have the name recognition of having NYU School of Medicine/NYU Medical Center on your resume
cons:
Each Department Chair basically sets the tone and culture of each department, as well as some rules, for example whether telecommuting is allowed or not, dress code, etc.  So the day to day work environment could be very different from employee to employee. For new employees this can make it hard to gauge what you might be getting into. I happen to work for someone who is ok, sometimes (not all) he can be a little manic and formal which tends to make employees anxious, and he enforces a no jeans/shorts/bare arms dress code.  This isn't unreasonable, but I am envious of a friend of mine who does the same job I do in a different dept, who is allowed to dress more comfortably and casually.  Particularly as in our position we dont really interface with the public very much, such as patients or donors. 

If you leave the institution before 3 years, you are not able to keep what NYU has contributed to your 401k/403b.

The other con is the location.  You either pay ALOT in rent to live nearby, or you are forced to commute in and out of lower manhattan.  You do get a pretax commuter benefit but it only covers about half the cost.  

This is a very busy place with tons always going on and to keep track of, and if you are not a doctor, its likely you will find yourself consistently assigned with additional work thats not in your job description.

Other than a one year review after hire, in my dept (again see my note about Chair setting culture) employees aren't given a review unless they ask for it. I suppose this is a good thing if you are a slacker, but for others it denies us an opportunity to talk about various (non-urgent) issues we might have, without having to start an awkward conversation.  

In speaking with certain people, I have learned that some employees in my dept have gotten 6 month bonuses and others have not, just because the people who received it asked for it. Even though the employees in question were the same quality and did the same quality work. This is unfair.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant in Mineola, NY
pros: The salary is great !
cons: Discrimination, Unfair Treatment of Minority’s.

review_title: It doesn't pay to be a consultant...
job_title: Technical Consultant in New York, NY
pros: The people, both colleagues and the employees that we support are friendly, helpful and quick to give appreciation and praise.
cons: As a consultant, there was no specific place for us to work. We would meet in the basement of a building each morning, waiting to find out where we would be working that day. The management structure is convoluted and the communication between hospital management and IT Management was poor and lacked any sort of organization, which meant that we really didn't discover what we were supposed to do until we actually arrived at the employee location.

review_title: AVoid the medsurg floors if you can. hoag 5 hog 6
job_title: Staff RN in Mineola, NY
pros: Excellent benefits, Fellow nurses are amazing, beautiful campus, Management is excellent and supportive of nurses! The new nurse residency program is AMAZING!
cons: No help from nursing assistants, Nurse to patient ratio 7:1, Have to baby the residents 99% of the time, God forbid you page stat labs for any things,

review_title: Don’t judge a book by its cover.
job_title: Lead Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Good salary and retirement contributions.
cons: Favoritism.  Limited career growth.  A lot of talk about how they want to promote their leading edge technology but it’s mostly talk.  Significant turnover of experienced, seasoned team members.  The majority of new employees are not mentored or experienced in their new role which speaks volumes to the future success of the organization.  Their onboarding program is minimal at best.  If you are passionate about your career you should look elsewhere , but if you want a “job” that pays well and you want to complain to your friends about how your manager doesn’t actually know how to manage people or technology, then this is the place for you.

job_title: Financial Systems Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Salary is competitive compared to the epic market. 5 weeks pto.
cons:
overworked and undervalued.
As systems analyst we worked 10-12 hours a day and its never enough. Management does not value their employees and are not professional. There is a high turn over in this department. In the matter of 6 months 10 employees resigned. They often disrespect and inappropriately communicate with their employees. On more than one occasion we have been quarantined during lunch hours, and after work hours. I have witnessed several employees crying at their desks. The morale is very low and quiet depressing. there is  no work/life balance.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The NYU Langone name is extremely reputable within New York City, as well as nationwide. Working for a company that prides itself in its values and mission statement, brings the rapport up amongst its staff. Great benefits and internal advancements.
cons: At times, it can be a stressful environment, but keeping in mind, the healthcare industry is always going to be fast-paced. Some leadership needs to understand we are in a new-age of business tactics and that understanding fully what each department/staff member does to benefit the company is beneficial for the entire organization.

review_title: Great medical institution, lousy place to work
job_title: Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits, great location, great place to stay if you are close to your retirement
cons:
No career path, no professional development, no mentoring, blatant favoritism, opaque inefficient management, at least in support departments. Sometimes unethical practices take place.
You will come here with the same set of skills as you will leave with, without acquiring any new knowledge, which, by the time when you want to leave will be completely obsolete. In other words, complete professional/intellectual stagnation.

review_title: It depends. if you have dreams....
job_title: Administrative in New York, NY
pros: I worked at NYU Medical Center for several years having various jobs in administrative roles.  I started with a really low salary considering cost of living in New York City, my education and background, and experience, BUT I did stay for the great benefits until I got a better position elsewhere.  I had three different positions, each one a sort of promotion from the last.  I rose up pretty quickly. If you are intelligent and hard working, you can do it. It's not difficult.  Salary rose with each position.
cons: Where to start?  I worked on the administrative side, so this has nothing to do with clinical or research. I also want to stress that I did not have have any issues with any doctors while working here, only the administrative side! 1)  I hated the cliques; the gossip; the fact that it's all educated middle aged women with children who stayed there for the benefits (and I am aware of the hypocrisy of this statement, as a woman, but just thinking about hospital administration brings me back to the person that I was and don't want to be.). The workers could have done something else, could have followed their dreams, but chose not to.  I didn't hate the people in general, I hated that they were all miserable there, and took it out on each other, which made everyone even more miserable.  It seemed like they were all out to get each other for some reason. Shouldn't we all work together?! They were happy with salary and benefits, but it was just an unpleasant work culture.  This isn't a dream job or a career, this is a paycheck until retirement.  No administrative job is a career, unless you are really high up on the totem pole.  Yet none of the people I worked with strived to get to the top, they strived to get to 5pm...  2) I did the job of my supervisor in all three jobs.  As a supervisor now, I understand the difficulties in a supervisory role (too much work, ability to delegate, being approachable, etc..), but this was a bit ridiculous.  I know exactly what each of my supervisors were supposed to do because I did all of their work on top of my own work.  Instead, knowing that they have an assistant, they took 3 hour lunches, dumped work on me, and expected me to stay late while they left early.  You can either manage or you can't, and these three could obviously not.  It got to the point that when I left, the person who had taken my last position at NYU contacted me asking if it was just them, of if the supervisor actually didn't do their job.  They stay in easy managerial roles for years, knowing that they probably won't get fired.  NYU doesn't fire incompetent people (con #4), meanwhile losing competent assistants every 6-8 months, who have gotten much better and much more interesting jobs elsewhere (i.e. left to follow their dreams, like I did).  Not all of the managers are this way, there are wonderful ones! Just the ones that I directly worked with were incapable of doing their jobs.  But, the fact that I had all three of my mangers be this way, statistically says to me that there are more bad managers than good ones.  One manager actually said to me that she is "not a micro-manager", but, then, was given a task by her manager, handed it to me, and just sat over my shoulder by my desk and commented while I completed the task.  This was all day every day that I worked in that position.  3) Is this really anyone's dream job?  No, this really is a paycheck with benefits.  It's paperwork, answering phones, and making sure you smile 8 hours a day doing mindless tasks. It's important work. Seriously and sarcastically. Without hospital administration there would be no hospitals (i.e. credentialing and licensing is key to even having a doctor see patients; organizing lectures and other events helps educate doctors more and advance in their fields; and having an administrative buffer basically leaves doctors alone to do their jobs, which is patient care or research to advance patient care!) It's easy work if you are competent, as I feel most (NOT ALL) are. There are people that do this, and do this well and put in 1000%, realizing how important it is. Being surrounded by people like that is encouraging and makes work worthwhile. However, most people at NYU are not like that. This job was not for me.  I left for graduate school several years ago and have never looked back!

The hiring process took months, during which the project was losing valuable time, as it was grant funded.

PIs are often willing to negotiate a better salary once you bring in a fellowship, that salary however will still be way below what you would need to consider yourself even lower middle class in New York. Vacations, 2 weeks per year, hello science, goodbye best of your life years. The way to go through it, I considered my postdoc as a temporary state of being, the City is fun and the community is great, so, iif you are willing to give up on some conveniences and take the postdoc gamble to see how you can boost your career with a couple of years of poverty and additional training, NYU is a great place to choose. review_title: Poor management, little chance of advancement for academics and downright dangerous environment
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY

I was happy to leave.

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: First, it's a great research hospital with lots of collaborations with industry which help to bring cutting edge technology to the center. Industry research scientist are also placed at the center and are supposed to be willing to help you complete your research. There is supposed to be a symbiotic relationship... the medical researchers help the industry representatives with feed back about the product to make the technology better and techniques developed on industry technology can be controlled be industry so they remain cutting edge. The medical center benefits b/c they are supposed to receive the newest upgrades and new products first. Industry representatives are also supposed to help researchers achieve their research goals. Instead of the medical researchers wasting their time fighting the technology to get what they want to achieve, they are supposed to be able to easily implement their ideas. If this symbiosis worked the way it should in theory it would be a great environment.
cons: No one wants to help each other. They just run their experiments and if they overcome a problem that might help someone else they keep it to themselves. Researchers often hide data and information from each other. The workplace shouldn't be a place to hang out but people should atleast get along professionally rather than trying to stab each other in the back. Senior researchers that have been at the institution for a while don't look to improve the career of grad students and post docs. Instead they look at them as work horses that must work themselves to death for the benefit of the senior researchers with nothing in return.This makes for an extremely hostile environment where research is hampered by egos and sometimes corruption. Industry reps are trying to produce products while attempting to help researchers. They are under stress and avoid helping researchers as much as possible. Senior researchers get the most attention b/c they have industry connections that can get representatives fired. I have never worked in a place where people waste them time with back handed comments as much as this place.

review_title: Started off as a good experience turned into a horror toxic environment.

review_title: Competitive RN Salary & Benefits. Could be better with other things.
job_title: Registered Nurse in New York, NY
pros:
- Salary ranging from 90-100k, with opportunities to advance up the clinical ladder (Nurse Clinician, Sr. Nurse Clinician) for better pay and schedules. 

- Yearly bonus for certifications available. 

- Tuition reimbursements for graduate nursing degrees at NYU. 

- Modern, beautiful facilities (and somewhat-modern if you're not at the new Kimmel Pavilion).

- Ambitious, intelligent, hard-working staff and community.
cons:
- No extra pay for charge nurses (something which seems to be standard in other Manhattan hospitals). This is also considering the no-brainer that some charge nurses are worked extremely hard, especially on more acute and critical-care floors. I've seen charge nurses regularly leave 1-2 hours after their shift has ended due to the number of emergencies and reports they need to attend to. 

- Nursing upper management can sometimes seem less than transparent. I worked during an important transitional period where nurses were being moved from Tisch Hospital over to Kimmel. Nurses who were training or hired to be on ICU floors were suddenly being told they would be shifted to non-ICU floors after weeks of speculation and rumors. Ironically, many of these same nurses ended up being recalled back to the ICU months later because of poor staffing ratios, worsening patient outcomes, and increased pressure placed on nurse managers from disgruntled nurses. Throughout all of this, we only heard from upper management every once in a while. 

- I personally disliked working at the new Kimmel Pavilion. While it has great patient amenities and operating rooms, the layout of this enormous building makes it difficult to find help or devices. Unlike in Tisch where you could easily look into the hallway to request help, Kimmel's enormous hallways and dispersed nursing stations make it difficult to see anyone. It sometimes takes walking an entire lap around the building to find a single device. Camaraderie amongst staff is also affected because you rarely get to work next to the same person longer than 2 days in a row. You might be working at one nursing station one day and then the opposite side of the building the next.

- This may be more of a culture issue, but I frequently saw travel nurses grow frustrated at the lack of collaboration between providers and nurses here. Travel nurses with close to 10 years of experience have reported getting their opinions or suggestions dismissed because they were newcomers. I've also experienced my fair share of negative, dismissive interactions with PA's and MD's that led to me escalating to my manager. Certain protocols regarding medicines and procedures are also more tightly regulated here, causing travel nurses to feel like they have less "autonomy" compared to other hospitals.

micro management

senior team is invisible to most staff
no path for professional development
culture of criticism
low morale is rampant

review_title: Apparently it really is who you know, not how much you work.
job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: I enjoyed working with a very diverse group of people from all over the country and the world. The staff is very professional yet laid back, preferring a more casual approach to work.
cons: Management. There is a serious issue with  nepotism in my current department. Senior staff tends to favor fellow teammates due to longer and more informal relationship. These teammates spend excessive amounts of time fraternizing, going off to eat during work hours, working overtime, and have excessive latenesses.

job_title: Nurse Clinician in New York, NY
pros:
- Great pay, including bonuses for specialty certifications, performance bonuses, and  opportunities for overtime
- Excellent benefits package (I paid only taxes on my masters degree thanks to their tuition remission program)
- Expanding hospital system with opportunities for growth and development
cons:
- As with nearly all hospitals (outside of CA), RN staffing can be a problem. Occasional short staffing = tight assignments, potentially unsafe nurse-patient ratios
- The hospital can't seem to expand fast enough! Lack of beds is a constant issue that can add stress to the units

job_title: Medical Secretary in New York, NY
pros: NYU enables its employees to gain a great amount of experience and Hands-On training. Allows employees to work in multiple areas within their Suite
cons: Some departments are on organized and lack communication or management. Politics aren't always right. Some staff members make departments feel like High School.

job_title: Registered Nurse
pros: Great pay and benefits . Base pay is 93,700 for all newly hired operating room nurses , and after 6 months 12,500 is added to your salary .
cons: Surgeons can be really nasty and rude . You are constantly being rushed to move the cases as quickly as possible .

review_title: It might be better for others than it is for me
job_title: Program Associate in Monroe, NY
pros: benefits are pretty good but there are no snow days
cons: each department seems to be its own individual fiefdom. many of the internal systems are complex and cumbersome, don't really seem up-to-date.  the departments that set them up are not responsible for updating user materials and much of the institution's training for the systems is 'canned' and useless

review_title: Blah and more blah is all I really have to say.
job_title: Postdoctoral Training Fellow in New York, NY
pros: They have frequent happy hours, which is relatively nice when the rest of time time you are worked to the bone and beating yourself up for the sake of science.
cons: It's in midtown and impossible to commute to.  One alternative is to actually live in the building that you work in (or across the street).  But then, there is a good chance that you will have years of your life shaved off in work hours.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits, can easily balance family/work, tuition benefits for those who want to take classes.
cons: No training opportunities, no room for growth or advancement, no departmental support.  I am not quite sure where to go after this position... Over the course of 7 months, I have reached out to three HR talent acquisition specialists, but they rarely reply.  My department has outgrown its space.

job_title: Per Diem RN in New York, NY
pros: Very nursing centered. Pro nursing. Nurses in high positions, Magnet status, opportunities for advancement. Best place I've worked as a nurse so far in my career.  Great ration on my floor (4:1), always looking to technologically advance. Always at the forefront of new and innovative ideas.
cons: Only the typical hospital issues. Usually not a lack of nurses but lack of nurse assistants i find.  Management issues, etc. Usual inpatient hospital stuff.

job_title: Programmer in New York, NY
pros: Lots of opportunity to move ahead. If you want to get ahead with the company there are lots of opportunities to do just that.
cons: Some people do not have good, productive, team-centric attitudes. This is a shame because there are more nice, normal people than not, but of course the negative ones stick out.

review_title: Poor leadership support and inconsistent promotion practices
job_title: Development Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Tuition remission and other benefits are substantial and varied to meet the needs of all employees. Facilities improvements throughout the medical center are impressive.
cons: Leadership support is lacking in many aspects, clear vision and direction is not provided.  Feedback and performance reviews are ineffective.

review_title: Great atmosphere, leadership, benefits. Preparation for future-opportunities could be improved.
job_title: Program Associate in New York, NY
pros: Friendly team and leadership, great benefits, good work/life balance
cons: While I've seen lots of folks with NYU Langone Health act as self-starters move up the ladder, I feel the company doesn't actually do enough to help.

job_title: Senior Information Security Risk Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
- Good benefits
- Starting pay is on par with industry
- Working hours are chilled out
- Lots of independence in managing your work
- professional development budgets allow to pursue certifications
cons:
- no big hikes, almost insignificant raises even if you perform very well.
- getting promoted takes time
- no cafeterias/cafes in office facilities

review_title: NYU is a great foot in the door
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: They offer competitive salaries, flexible workshifts, and opportunities for advancement
cons: Sometimes the workload is overwhelming especially if you are the individual in that position for the entire department. Sometimes you are asked to do things that is not in your job description.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Lots of autonomy. Kind support staff. Ability to take days off without issue. Benefits are sufficient.
cons: Increased work load and responsibility with no increase in salary or raises. Various off site clinics to cover that require commuting during lunch break. Clinics do not have personnel dedicated to write letters, fill forms, or obtain prior authorization for medication. These tasks fall to the provider. Office hours are sparse and always in danger of being removed.

job_title: Research Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Benefits are really good, pay is comparable to other academic medical centers (highest I've seen in the area), they really invest in their CRCs/research teams and provide a lot of comprehensive training days, the work you're doing is really great and they help you hit the ground running.
cons: Salaried, so they don't pay for lunch (35 hours), different departments have varied/mixed signals for expectations. Strict employee handbook (dress code, appearance, late policy)

review_title: A great experience at NYU, it expanded my knowledge of patient care, provided clarity of the various insurance company.
job_title: Finance in New York, NY
pros: Great working enviornment, more on the faculty side
cons: Challenges of working here, is not too many open positons, I think that staff should be able to work in different locations at the center within their scope of educaiton and experience

job_title: Management in New York, NY
pros: Technology is top of the line. Some  of the management is helpful and kind.
cons: Upper Mgmt only focuses on what you are doing wrong. The culture is more punitive then positive. Many are not approachable. Managers and staff afraid to ask questions. Many people do not respond to emails. Change is slow. Too many hurdles to make changes.

job_title: Data Analyst in New York, NY
pros: This was great place to learn, but bad place to grow as specialist. After working at NYU for over 5 years, I wasn't promoted even though I asked management for promotion.
cons: hard to get promotion. Top management hire supervisors from outside of the company. New supervisors don't know how to do the job.

review_title: If you are looking for IT -- look elsewhere.
job_title: Systems Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Benefits are very good. Teamwork with employees below the director level is excellent -- many dedicated professionals. There are still some good teams to be found in some areas.
cons: A managerial snake-pit! An NYU ex-pat termed it, "the most toxic place I've ever seen." 5 ys ago this would have been a 5 star review but managerial purges have taken a toll.  If you're looking for a Machiavellian coal mine to work in, this is it.

job_title: Research Data Associate in New York, NY
pros: Great experience working at NYU Langone Medical Center. I worked in a very diverse department. I worked in public health research and was able to recieve some patient/clinical experience.
cons: I really did not like working in the research field. The company is growing fast and at times space capacity did not fit the number of employees.

job_title: Department Administrator in New York, NY
pros: Committed to action - not words - on diversity, inclusion, internal career development and promotion, excellence, and respect for work-life balance.
cons: Unyielding drive to continually improve is what makes the organization fresh, exciting, and innovative.  Although leadership is sensitive to avoid it, change fatigue can happen periodically when many critical change projects intersect at one time.

review_title: The research itself can be interesting and colleagues are great but the work environment is bureaucratic and political.
job_title: Project Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Great educational opportunities to participate in free lectures and seminars.
cons: No room for advancement or meaningful professional development, stifling environment that doesn't reward initiative or creativity, poor management that underestimates the skills of its employees and lacks strategic vision.

job_title: Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Benefits, Salary and some of the people are great.  It really depends if you get on a good team or a bad team.  I happened to be placed on a bad team full of negative vibes.
cons: Bad management and direction.  Not supported by upper management either.

review_title: Very corporate for an academic institution
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY

cons: It is a very bureaucratic and corporate-like institution where HR is most prevalent. A minor downside is the amount of daily junk emails from university

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY

review_title: Great place to do a PhD

job_title: Financial Analyst in New York, NY

job_title: Program Manager in New York, NY

review_title: Good career opportunites but poor compensation for postdocs

job_title: Administrator in Brooklyn, NY

review_title: Amazing company- Very supportive of personal development and education!

job_title: Senior Program Coordinator in New York, NY

Pros vary by department
very flat office structure in my department makes it hard to get promotions or raises in your current role - I'd have to internally transfer to get a promotion, but I love the program I work on so I'm stuck.

review_title: This is  a solid institution on a rapid upward swing in both performance and reputation.

review_title: Good pay and benefits, but can be disorganized

review_title: Lots of amazing people, leadership not trustworthy
job_title: Graduate Assistant in New York, NY

review_title: Overall a nice place to work with lots of opportunities for movement.
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: benefits, location, 403B match, lots of seminars and interesting lectures
cons: bureaucratic, health test requirements, slow to change way things are done, opaque leadership style, staff infrastructure is not as fully developed as it could be which leads to people doing the work of multiple jobs

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: As the Section on Value and Effectiveness (SOLVE) is relatively young, there is reasonable potential for growth. Additionally--and this can be a pro and a con, depending on your point of view--you get the opportunity to wear many hats and undertake projects/positions you wouldn't in a larger, more established department, which provides great experience. There are a lot of very intelligent people in the department, and of course, NYU Langone Medical Center at large is a wonderful and renowned institution.
cons:
-The biggest problem with working here is the department president, to whom everyone reports either directly or indirectly. Though a good researcher and fundraiser, he is unfortunately the most ineffective manager of humans I have ever encountered in my long career in both academia and the private sector. He micromanages to point of nullifying his employees' jobs, he is astonishingly rude and nasty, he lacks the most basic of management skills, and like many people who excel at a single thing, he has extreme tunnel vision, and completely fails to see situations from the multiple perspectives required of a decent manager. Add to that the fact that is the most miserable human being I've ever encountered, and this all makes for a pretty awful work environment. He deliberately cultivates an environment of fear and misery, and seems to go out of his way to make all of his underlings (that's a very deliberate noun choice) feel insignificant and in constant fear for their jobs. I regularly had coworkers come to me in tears, devastated with the way he had publicly berated them for some perceived error (very often, his own error!), deliberately embarrassed them in front of their coworkers and/or managers, and belittled and screamed at them for no apparent reason. Scarcely a day passed that I didn't actively deal with personnel issues of his needless creation.
- This department is very underfunded, so there are constantly promises made about imminent increases in staff, resources, and support that NEVER materialize.
-The department is also terribly understaffed, so one person regularly does the job of 5-7 people, and zero appreciation is expressed, no matter how hard you work.
- The morale in this office is the lowest I've ever experienced, and any attempts to raise morale are treated as hostile threats to the management. May employees frequently commiserated over what a miserable environment it was.
-As is commonplace in many academic environments, it is nearly impossible to implement any real change, as management likes to say, "well this is the way we've always done it," no matter how unsuccessful the results. This is no place for creative self-starters!

review_title: Great working environment with excellent work/life balance.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY

job_title: Runner in New York, NY

review_title: Nice place to work, but seems to have communication issues in administrative departments.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY

job_title: in Briarwood, NY

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: I gave it 1 star because of management.  Overall though NYU has excellent benefits and raises.  Great location.
cons: Now the cons....Although NYU instills in orientation that they do not tolerate a hostel work environment or retaliation...its a lie.  In my department, in the 5 years I worked there, 5 employees have gone to HR after being singled out, nit-picked on and/or forced to quit.  Management doesn't look into issues, they will just go by what someone tells them.  Takes someones word because this manager "doesn't want to get involved" and doesn't have time to know what each department does.  Review time comes around and they actually say, "I don't know what you do, so does such and such area apply to you?"  Definitely plays favorites.  Shows employees other employees salaries.  When something is told to them in private, by the time you get back to your desk, the whole office already knows about it.  HR says they have your back, but they just email the manager and tells them that such and such employee contacted HR and the situation is sent back to the manager to again, "not" deal with it!!!  This after attempts are made to rectify the situation with the manager.  Many complaints about this manager and they are still there.  Family members working in the same department.  I thought this was not allowed.  Management knows staff is on facebook, watching youtube and does nothing about it while others within that area of the department work their butts off.  The pay is great but after awhile, money doesn't buy happiness and your health and sanity level is overall more important.  Many times employees within this department have wanted to go straight to Grossman to complain because no one listens to you.
